e 18 before I did procure
e meeting of
e Stats,
I found it very requisite to speake w
th
M
r
Barnevelt
at if so be
he could be wonne to undertake his former offer, we might joint-
lie cast a plott, to sette
e matter forward, & allso make if need
required, some speciall additi
o
, to
e forme of
e verball, w
ch
yo
r
L.
had c
o
ceaved. But I should use so many words, to make a full
report of his answers to me. The cheifest were to this effect,
t
his forwardnes & zeale, to doe service to both sides, had bene
termed in
England
simulati
o
& c
u
ning:
at
e state of their
affaires since he and I talked, had bene notablely changed: and
at
e college of
e states was waxen very jealous of his dealing in
this matter (allbeit he did not thinke
t
they know
e particu-
larityes) so as now
e second time to intermeddle in
e same, it
was to hazard ov
r
much his creditt in
e Contrey, if it should not
succeed to theyr generall liking, w
ch
he had no res
o
to put in ad-
venture, sith it touched him no more th
e
every m
a
besides.
This was so in debate for 2 dayes together: but yett in
e end
w
th
very much adoe, & many forks of
suasions, he made me
this answere, That although it were apparant,
at since
e
time of
t
ouverture, there had bene many things hapned
here, w
ch
were evident impeachm
ts
to
e course
t
he proposed,
yett he c
o
tinued in his hope,
at to staie in good assurance
of her
Ma
ties
amitye, & to obteine a full release of her her demands
e Contrey might be drawe to yelde to some offer beyond their abi-
litye: wherin he would take paine, to satisfie her Ma
tie
by all
e wayes he could invent: howsoev
r
there had passed
just occasi
o
of discouragem
t
: but yet it was not in his
power to find so readie meanes, to attaine to
t
he would,
as wh
e
it was Integrum. For w
ch
it would be behoofull to
have a little patience, till his fellowes might be brought by
convenient degrees to allow
e proposall, It was allso to be
thought on
t
he of all others might not now as at first
propound
e matter in their college: but if I would be thinke
me how to sett it once a foote, I should see every day by his
carefull proceeding,
at he forslowed no occasi
o
, to second me
soundly. Wherupp
o
I tould him
t
my comissi
o
would not beare
at I might use any speach in theyr publik assemblie of
any new moti
o
, as proceeding fr
o
her Ma
tie
but yet I
would adventure after time, as I had uttered her pleasure
unto th
e
, to cast out a word in generall tearmes, by
way of proposing my privat opini
o
, & w
th
a trew protestation,
that I had

t

m
issi
o
fr
o
her Ma
tie
to doe it, to such effect as this,
t
I had weighed w
th
my selfe, very often & throughly, as much as
they could alledge in excuse of their refusalls &
t
I saw not w
th
-
standing how backward so ev
r
they had shewed th
e
selves,
t
they
might easily devise, to satisfie her Ma
tie
& make no dangerous di-
minuti
o
of
e strength & wellfare of
e contry: & if after up
o
this in their private cosultati
o
he would take a fitt occasion
to provoke his Colleugues to a conference & to send some 2 or 3
to know
e meanes
t
I could plotte to give her Hig
nes
contentat
o
n, I
would th
e
as of my self breake
e ice unto his hands, & rec
o
mend such
an ouverture, although I meant to make it better, as we had in c
o
municati
o
Of this kind of proceeding he tooke good liking so as 3 dayes agoe
obtaining audience of
e States after I had imparted
e poynt
of my
charge I am to deliver my private advice, as I had formerly used
in many other causes, w
th
theyr approbati
o
but allwayes w
th
a preface
of submissi
o
to theyr judgem
t
& w
th
a speciall protestati
o
t
I speke but of
my selfe, w
th
out
e notice of her Ma
tie
I requested th
e
to thinke,
t
allthough for
e present, her highnes had bene pleased for some greater
c
o
siderations, to seme to say little & to winke at theyr dealinges, yet
sith it was a matter
at touched her in hono
r
in regard of her earnest
& oft
e
pursuite &
e sensure of
e world w
ch
wold follow up
o
e issue
she would not so give it out, but wh
e
e seas
o
served fo
r
it, they might be
trobled w
th
e fruites of a Princes indignati
o
. So it might befall
t
these spanish preparations would prove but a scarre crow,
t
e Enemie
might otherwise be drive to his shiftes, by some notable domage, or
t
they in their affayres might atteine by some attempt, to a great
amendm
t
of their meanes in any of w
ch
cases, they were to imagine in
their wisdome, if it would cost th
e
very deare, so
t
her Ma
tie
might
ceave,
t
it were not to ruine
e State of their contrey wheras now
if they would they might prevent it all in tyme, w
th
some kind pres
e
tati
o
to be made by their deputies such as she might accept w
th
her
dignity & honor & they afford no willing minds w
th
out
e imparing
of their Estate. I had no such occasi
o
to know their estate, as
they th
e
selves, yet of some what I was certaine & could cleere it unto
th
e
by plaine demonstrati
o
t
e contry was provided of c
o
petent
meanes for a reasonable offer, so as if they would but fall to fashi
o
a project & rec
o
mend it to
e people w
th
some cauti
o
& care, as they
had
e skill to handle it well, it was like enough to passe w
th
out any oppositi
o
.
They should therfore looke unto it, & spedelie take hould of this offred
opportunitye, & not spare a little labo
r
to c
o
pound so great a matter.
Wherein I for my selfe would be readie, wh
e
they would to c
o
mu-
nicate further, & to yeeld any ayde in other sort, c
o
curring w
th
e dutie
& creditt of my place. To
t
w
ch
I declared in her Ma
tyes
name
they made me this answere, That they marveyled out of measure,
at
e sharppnesse of my message, wh
e
as they in there l
re
s did so
playnlye reporte
e state of their affayres as they thought it possible,
if her hig
nes
had vouchsafed to ponder ev
r
ye reas
o
w
th
exquisite
ballance

ballance of her princelie judgm
t
, but
t
she would have give way to
their true allegations. They would consider further of it, & as occasi
o
might be offred, I should know their resoluti
o
. And as for
t
w
ch
I had
uttered of my owne pro
moti
o
they tooke it as proceeding fr
o
affec
o
n
to them & of inwarde desire to make a crooked arrow. Fo
r
w
ch
they
gave me many thanks: but yett touching
t
matter they found
it very ticklish to be bruted abroad,
t
they & I were in talk how
to find out a way, to dissolve
e contract w
th
her Ma
tie
& to take
order for remborsem
t
w
ch
might be hurtfull to th
e
selves for not
being authorised, & perilous allso otherwise, fo
r
pushing on
e
people to some other allterati
o
. Nev
r
e lesse they would seeme it
& discusse it amongest th
e
selves, & after a while I should have
word how farre they durste proceed. I had presentlie therup
o
some further talke w
t
M
r
Barnevelt
, by whome I was info
r
med
t
e answere made unto me, went currant in their meeting as
take to be grounded up
o
e very true reas
o
& circ
u
stance of
thinges, as theyr state standeth now, & in
e nature of this cause.
For w
ch
e matter yett required some time of digesting, w
ch
he
would sett forward
e sonest he could, & travell to effect it w
th
his greatest dexteritye. For if so be his collegues should be urged
very hastely, he thought
t
out of questi
o
, they would ether not
give care, or if they should & should not like, it were no more
to be renewed: wherupp
o
he would indevour not directlie by
suasions, for
t
were to op
e
but by other kind of preambles, to
prepare underhand
e humors of his fellowes w
ch
would be therfore
e harder, because they are not one mans chilldren & hardly meet in
once conceipt, in
e weightyest causes of
e contrey. The lest
c
o
tributing provinces, is
Guelderland,
Overissel,
Utrecht,
&
Groe-
ningh
e
are none of
e stiffest in refusing a peace, & have nothing
so much feling of her Ma
tyes
offence, as
Holland
&
Zel and,
t
stand
up
o
their traffick & can quicklye make
e reckning to have much
danger they are subject, if her Ma
tie
would be draw
e
to make
traill of her puissance. Never
e lesse bycause Holland & Zeland, by
reas
o
of their greatnesse, give
e [laio] in a maner to all
e
rest he will first, take upp
o
him to sound
e chiefest sort of th
e
& if they will c
o
prehend it as beneficiall for
e state, he will make
e lesse doubt of
e residue of
e Provinces.
It cometh happely to passe,
t
he is newlie now appointed w
th
certaine principalls of Holland, to goe presentlie for Zeland, a-
bout some publick causes, w
ch
he doth account will keep him awaye
some x or xij dayes & give him very good leisure for managing
this matter w
th
those of
e Province. And then will be th
e
after
about a fortnight, a full meeting Holland, where he is bent to doe his best,
& therafter

hand w
th
some others, of
e other lesser Provinces, & wh
e
e time
shall be for it, he will procure to have me called to explicate my
meaning, in my former propositi
o
, & th
e
after to c
o
clude & deter-
mine upp
o
it. So as I am in good hope to know of o
r
on; w
th
in
4 or five weekes. Once I hould my selfe assured,
t
there willbe
no defect in M
r
Barnevelt
indevo
r
s: who is very earnest w
th
me,
t
there may be no speeches of this
t
he entendeth, no
r
no
menti
o
of his name, as of a plotter of this Project, w
ch
will
rather disadv
a
tage, th
e
advance her highnes service, & may
adv
e
ture purchase him a n
u
ber of bitter foes.
It may also more end
a
ger, th
e
further this matter, for me to deall w
t
others, aswell as w
t
him, unlesse
t
some m
e
of th
e
selves will give
e
first occasi
o
, as hath bene done by Barnevelt. Againe I finde it not
so easye, where mens natures are so jelous, as they are in this Con[trey]
& so fearfull to list
e
to any new devises, to gett th
e
sodd
e
ly to
a point of such c
o
sequence aswill bereave th
e
of
e benefitt of a sin-
guler treatye, w
th
a Prince of so much power whose countenance &
aid hath maintaned there Estate, so many yeares together,
against
e force of such an enemy. For w
ch
I take it to be best
till
e matter shall be riper, to use
e help of one alone, who is
allreadye gained for it, & for his creditt & experience doth serve
in steed of many others: as likewise I must say
t
for his sound-
nesse of dealing, I have had it in triall for a n
u
ber of yeares,
in very many devises, in w
ch
I have found him oft
e
harshe in res-
pect of his cariage, but allwayes very trustie in regard of
fo
r
-
mance, where his promise hath bene past. And so I trust I shall
have cause to report in this case: whereof I will advrtise as occa-
si
o
shall be give having now no other mater for
e affaires of
this state, nor for forraine occurrence,
t
doth deserve to hould
e
longer.
For w
ch
I take my h
u
ble leave. Fr
o
e Hage J
a
4 95.
Theyr purpose was heere to have sent theyr deputy for
England
about
e first of
e next moneth, w
ch
is tallked of noe
more, nor as far as I c
a
learne, is not intended now at
all, for
e speech
t
I delivered in
e name of her highnes
unlesse
t
happelie this be granted, wherin I am busied at
this present.
